title: Service Level Target calculations
content:
Service Management offers a complete set of Service Level Target (SLT) definitions for incident, request, change, task, problem, and custom records. As a Service Management administrator, you can change the default behavior of these built-in target definitions by editing the Service Level Target definition records.

Calculations

Service Management runs a backend scheduler job to calculate the elapsed time for each Service Level Target. The calculation frequency varies—Service Management decides the next calculation time by considering two factors:

  • an interval that varies according to the time left or overdue compared with the target time of a Service Level Target. The less time left or overdue, the smaller interval. The smallest interval is one minute, and the largest is one day. 
  • an interval that is equal to one percent (1%) of the duration of the SLT definition.

Service Management calculates two next calculation time values according to the two intervals, and chooses whichever is sooner.

Service Management calculates duration from the time the Start SLT rule runs. For details about how Service Management calculates the durations for Service Level Targets, see Service Level Target duration calculation details.

Pay attention to the factors that affect the SLT calculations, which are described below.

SLT-related fields in a record

If you update any SLT-related fields (SLA, OLA, Service, Priority, the assignment group, or the customer field) of a record, Service Management applies the changes correctly to any calculation in progress. For example, if you change the priority in an incident from "Slight disruption" to "Severe disruption", Service Management adjusts the calculation in progress to apply this new value.

If the Priority field is empty, the target type is shown as Not defined. 

Actual service or offering in a record

If you change the actual service or offering assigned to a record, the Service Level Target definition might change or even become obsolete. If the Service Level Target definition changes, the Service Level Target calculation in progress is cleared, and any new or changed target definition calculations begin. In this case, the time already elapsed may or may not be included in the new target definition calculations, according to whether the record's workflow process is changed or not.

Condition Time already elapsed is included in new calculations?
The record's workflow process has not changed Yes
The record's workflow process has changed

No.

For example, if you change the offering on a request, and as a result the request has changed from a Service request to a Support request and the SLT is reinitialized. In this case, the time already elapsed before the offering is changed is not included in the new SLT calculations.

Process type of a record

If you change the process type of a record (for example, you change a support request to a service request), the SLT calculation is reinitialized and the already elapsed time is not included in the new calculation.

Timezone and work schedule

  • Time zone and work schedule: Service Management calculations take into account the time zone and work schedule specified in the Service Level Target definition. 
  • Applying changes to an SLT definition: When you make changes to a Service Level Target definition, the changes require an update to every record using that target definition. The changes will take effect automatically within 24 hours. Alternatively, you can click Apply now at the top of the Service Level Management page or the Time Period Management page to begin updating the Service Level Target definitions immediately. The amount of time to complete the update depends on the number of affected records. If one of those records is open, click Refresh to see the updates. If you make additional changes to a Service Level Target definition after applying the changes manually, the Apply now button will reappear after a few minutes.

New chat request

When a new chat request is submitted, the elapsed target duration is reset.

Notifications

Service Management sends email notifications as a Service Level target approaches a breach threshold.

The default email template includes the following information:

  • Service
  • Category
  • Priority
  • Status
  • Description
  • SLT type
  • SLT name
  • SLT target time
  • Group
  • Offering
  • Agreement

  • The notifications are sent for all target types except for Approval targets for Service requests.
  • You can enable and disable the email notifications in the SLT settings tab in Studio. For more information, see SLT settings.
  • After you create a custom target type through Lists > Target type and then create a new custom record type, once you set a business rule to send notifications for this custom target type, no email notifications will be sent. This is a known limitation, to work around this, you can make any changes to the Target type list and click Save. This allows the list to be refreshed and notifications can be successfully sent.
  • Existing Task’s SLT won’t be started for calculation.
  • We only support SLT for manual tasks. That is, we don't support SLT for automated tasks, approval tasks, and external tasks.
  • The task node will show the SLT.Next target date for manual tasks that are not at the "Not running" stage. Currently, up to 249 manual tasks can be displayed (with task SLT.Next target time). When there are more than 249, a message pops up and the task node doesn't show the SLT.Next target time for those active manual tasks.
  • You can use the filter function for Request, Change, Incident, Task, Problem, and custom record types, the filter can be remembered for the current user.
  • You can configure rules under After applying changes for release/article/proposal record types to sync the service to task: ‘Set fields on related tasks’. Rule template looks like this:
    If${current_update.RegisteredForActualService.IsChanged}On related Task records with PlatformTaskType IN ${'ManualTask'} PhaseId NOT IN ${union('Completed','Failed','Cancel')}, set AffectsService: ${entity.RegisteredForActualService}
